*1917 – Phyllis Nicolson, English mathematician and academic (d. 1968)
* John Crank and Phyllis Nicolson describe the Crank–Nicolson method in numerical analysis.

In numerical analysis, the Crank–Nicolson method is a finite difference method used for numerically solving the heat equation and similar partial differential equations. It is a second-order method in time. It is implicit in time, can be written as an implicit Runge–Kutta method, and it is numerically stable. The method was developed by John Crank and Phyllis Nicolson in the mid 20th century.

Crank's main work was on the numerical solution of partial differential equations and, in particular, the solution of heat-conduction problems.  He is best known for his work with Phyllis Nicolson on the heat equation, which resulted in the Crank–Nicolson method.
